title: 'No ancient culture but Greece was more fertile in philosophy than India'. In Western philosophy we can see a gradual growth in the thought process. But we do not see it in India. Is it due to the rich diversity we enjoyed? What do you think? - Quora

response.answer_text: A fish moving with the current can’t measure the river. So, neither the fish of the Greek river nor the fish of the Indian river would have an idea about their respective Rivers of philosophy. The West thinks that its “imposing physical posture” is the defining legacy of its gnostic past that began with the advent of Greece. On the other hand, the East (India) thinks that its “circulatory introspection” is the defining legacy of its gnostic past that began with the advent of Jambudvipa. These are the two fishes floating away in two great rivers, thinking that they know their habitats. An unmanned survey ship with no specific bias could do the job of finding out the relative sizes and depths of these two rivers, provided it had the requisite gadgets. To cut the story short, let’s be practical. Pick up Bharatamuni’s “Natryashastra”, the encyclopedic treatise on dramaturgy and histrionics. This is one of Ancient India’s hundreds of such treatise of such acuity and acumen. It is quite doubtful if Greek standard of intellectual analysis and creation is as high. Because it was getting admixed with ostentatious rhetoric and sophistry right from the beginning. India lost track of own intellect due to its failure to mine the relatively small requisite quantity of “tin” that was necessary to turn its huge heaps of “copper” into bronze through “alloying”. Copper is here the metaphor for “high-quality general philosophy” when tin is that for “gender ecstasy and inspiration”. Somewhere due to a transient inattention, a fatal fault crept into the Indian socio-cultural ambience initiating a retardation caused by “agencies of trans-intellectual kind”. The reason was obviously the false notion of and obsession about “superiority of pure knowledge” over “practical knowledge”, when the later should have been the priority. As a consequence, India began to miss “honey-sweet experiences” and “perennial inspiration” for forwardly momentum. On the Greek side, this omission didn’t occur and “gender power” was fully exploited to drag their chariot of civilization uphill and forward through thick and thin. The “intellectual wagon” would be the natural tow of the chariot, anyway. Thus, on the Greek/ Western side, the shortfall on the intellectual aspect was made good by the “social pragmatism and proactiveness”. Woman freedom, sexual freedom, positive pornography etc came on the side of the “trans-intellectual agencies” of the Western Civilization. On the Greek/ West side, unaware of the concealed identities of the agencies of civilization, “scientific attitude” has been pulled out at random to serve to represent the agencies of civilization. It may not be the truth. India was relatively more scientific long ago, but it lost at the “gender crossroads”. The West is winning for reasons other than “scientific attitude” which isn’t any longer in possession of them at this moment, anyway. The very “first principle of science” that calls for and empowers “universal/ ingenious/ cross-faculty thinkers” to become the source of the “guiding hypothesis” and to become the master of the organization of contextual employed specialists/ professional who would be carrying out the corroborative experimentation has been abandoned by the West long ago. This also has pushed mankind and globe to the brink of catastrophes and apocalypses as the cumulative civilization has become uncontrollable under the avaricious influence of the non-science. So, if you are listening, you can visualize very well that India has entered a period of endless hibernation to escape the cold of an unending winter which has been invited by its “gender stupidity”. India doesn’t now need to be more “intelligent”. It needs to be “gender-wise”. Fast revival would be around the corner thereafter. Coming back to your query, well, most portions of your long query needs to be retold to bring back consistency.

Evolution took a different path in India. Greece didn't evolve in it's own way . Christianity took Greek and Europe centuries before. Greeks had measured Circumference of Earth and had lot of scientific knowledge and philosophical knowledge,but monotheistic strict Christianity killed everything. Later Protestantism made some progress and French revolution happened in France. Later scientific revolution took place. This was the milestone of success for Europeans. But in India all philosophies were termed as mythology by Western-Indologists . China and India deserve lot more attention and recognition . We had come up lot of mathematical formulas which Europeans found centuries later.
